title: List of Character Alignment in New Lore
body:
Hey guys!
So I've been recently thinking about how a lot of the characters in the new lore have really interesting, diverse, and sometimes not so clear motivations. So I tried putting together a list of their _overall_ alignments (D&D style :P) however some of them are actually somewhat ambiguous so we'll be doing our best! :P Anyway lets get started.

-----

Quick summary of the alignment system:
Lawful Good: **The Knight**   _Follows strict moral code, always fights evil._
Neutral Good : **The Hero** _Always does the right thing, even if it goes against the law/certain morals._
Chaotic Good : **The Rebel**  _Fights the system to do whats right._
Lawful Neutral : **The Judge**  _Believes strongly in justice, carries out certain ideals no matter what._
True Neutral : **The Outsider**  _Doesn't go out of his way to harm others, but doesn't protect them either. Morally ambiguous._
Chaotic Neutral : **The Nomad**  _Cares only about him/her self, ignores moral codes/the law._
Lawful Evil : **The Overlord**  _Cares about power above all else, uses the law to enforce his power._
Neutral Evil : **The Villain**  _Pursues evil at all costs, not for enjoyment._
Chaotic Evil : **The Psychopath**  _Exists purely to destroy, revels in acts of evil._

Anyway these are pretty basic guidlines, but they are not set in stone and many characters may border different alignments.

Looking at this I think its really telling that most champions are Lawful Neutral, it shows the direction riot is taking with the new lore. A lot of the champions fight for ideals/something bigger than themselves. Honestly this usually makes for really great stories . I think its also interesting that there are so few true neutral characters. True Neutral characters seem to not interact with the story line as often which makes sense since riot is trying to make Runnaterra more immersive and what not.

ANYWAY, I'll change any of the allignments if you guys think I got them wrong. Hope you enjoyed!

Man, i love me some old school rpg alignment stuff!

For pretty much all of the new and updated mortal characters you can see the writers built in a journey from one alignment to another.  This can be a subtle shift (like Illaoi, Shen, or Azir) or the begining of a huge swing ( Ekko, Sivir, Zed)

Imho When writing or playing an old school rpg a character should always be transitioning between alignments.  (Or even better, facing a split in the road towards two).   So for instance i would argue orginal Sivir was neutral evil bordering on chaotic evil.  She's selfish, (ie evil)  with no respect for the law (chaotic), though some respect for tradition (neutral).     

BUT look at her color text... She changing and begining to doubt how she's lived her life...   That means her alignment is shifting radically.  

Thus i would argue alignment should have at least two parts. (Potentially three)  Alignment of who they were and who they are becoming.

Fun list though!

This is where alignment unfortunately fails. Neutral is extremely vaugely defined. I for example would argue that a one dimensionally selfish character would be charotic neutral, whereas chaotic evil is a person who enjoyus doing evil.

My understanding of the good- neutral - evil split was selflessness.   So Good is some one who will put others safety and well being above their own.  Evil = Selfish.  Neutral is just most of us.   I don't think its really about people enjoying "evil" as the alignment system is based on people.  Evil is the thief who kills someone to steal their gold.

My rule of thumb on alignment goes like this:
- good characters want other people to be well
- neutral characters want themselves to be well
- evil characters want to hurt other people

Though I never liked d&d's alignment system, it's too simplistic and restrictive, especially in a setting that's not clearly split into good/neutral/evil (like e.g. Dragonlance)

Just to jump in, that's not quite exact. For example, a Lawful Good character would have absolutely no qualms about instantly executing someone they find guilty, whereas a Chaotic Good character might be more open to discussion. The former will 'hurt' for his cause, and the latter will 'help' for his whims.

The selflessness test is generally the most accepted one. A good character will do his best to act for the sake of others, a neutral character will act based on the situation, and an evil character will act for his own goals.

I mostly agree, I'm also not a native english speaker and find it difficult to say exactly what I mean. With "hurting others" I didn't necessarily mean to inflict physical pain but... oh well, you're still not wrong :)

As said, character are often very nuanced and I think alignment is a very limited tool to describe then, because a) it doesn't distinguish between intent and action (what if I think I'm doing something good but am actually doing something evil?) and b) it's just too broad and generic, most characters are more complex than what goes under an alignment and you either ignore part of what a character is, or you put most characters under "neutral".

That's not to say that one can't discuss about what alignment a character would be, of course ^^

>My understanding of the good- neutral - evil split was selflessness.

Yeah, this is my best way of defining the differences between the two groups, particularly on a D&D alignment chart. 

However I will admit one of the problems with this perspective is what about someone who does pretty terrible things for the greater good?  I mean this person may not be acting selfishly, but he's also not doing things people would like or be proud of.

Yeah I agree that the champs have an evolving alignment. Admittedly I tried to create an alignment list before but I quit because it require multiple refinement for each champions and I am quite bias so I wasn't up for the task. 

Since you did say champ have evolving alignment I wanted to share who I believe to have gone through them.

First is Miss Fortune, I believe she started at someone along the line of neutral evil. Neutral evil because she was aiming to take down the order in Bilgewaters but she was abiding by it rules because she didn't want too much attention. She is consider evil because she was selfish and driven by revenge she didn't care about the consequence of her action. 

After defeating Gangplank she became more of a Neutral Good, she wanted reestablish order which make her lawful but being that it is Bilgewater  she also have to be sly something more on the chaotic side and she is good because she is trying to save Bilgewater from itself.

Another evolving champion is Leona however I think she went in a circle. At first she is neutral good, she has respect to the law on in this case it is tradition but she didn't let tradition stop her from doing what she believe to be good. When she was taken in by the Solari she became Lawful Good. The will of the Solari is above all else. 

When she was in this alignment she was "brainwash" by the Solari, under this alignment she tried to kill Diana. After becoming an Aspect she return to a Neutral Good where she still have a strong belief in the Solari but isn't bound by it because she is enlighten and know what is coming. What I love about her evolution is that at her core she is good.

Yeah I think miss fortune is in an interesting place--  for bilgewater she's pretty lawful... and she does live by a code.  But it rules would be foreign to most of us.   So neutral evil is probably a good spot for her.    I think she believes what she's doing is justified (maybe even seeing herself as Lawful good) but she's on a very dark path.   A well worn Nietzsche quote comes to mind....

There's a quote in the fourth chapter of Shadow and Fortune that I just love.  It's at the end, where Miss Fortune is talking to Lucian.

"“Then I’ll say farewell and good hunting,” she said, standing and dusting her britches. “I hope you find what you’re looking for. Just know that you can lose yourself to revenge.”

She knows WAY more about "losing yourself to revenge" than she thinks, I'd wager.  The ironymeter is reacting pretty strongly.

These I would disagree with a couple:

{{champion:21}} is definitely evil.  Killing people for revenge (esp bystanders) is selfish and therefore evil.  She can justify this to herself and probably thinks she's good--- but she hasn't walked that walk yet.   She is definitely in transition.

{{champion:420}} is definitely good.  Her god is a strange one with very different views on life than our culture.  But Illaoi is absolutely motivated by her faith and to help people--  it's just sometimes to help you... she has to slap the shit out of your soul.   

{{champion:15}} started as chaotic evil I think. She was blade for hire-- with no qualms about killing innocent people for money.   She's in motion though.

Illaoi's explicit job is to expose innocents to a lethal struggle. She does this based on her faith and institution of priests. I'm sure she can justify to herself that this is necessary, but she takes their fate in her hands and culls those that her God finds unworthy. This is lawful neutral at best, where she takes action based on her faiths doctrine and accepts that her intervention is often an execution.

True.  I'm super biased on her (working from inside a character's head will do that) 


So with my rose colored glasses- I give her a pass 'cause--  She is completely about the larger good. She knows death isn't the end-- and there are things far worse than death.  She wants everyone she tests to pass-- but she also knows that if they don't it's better for bilgewater, the universe, and for them-- to take a mortal mulligan.  (better luck next time!)   

Writing Gangplank or Jhin, these are selfish people-- inside their heads is all about what they feel they are owed or deserve --at the expense of others.  Illaoi is the opposite she has incredibly capacity for empathy-- and is desperately trying to help as many people as she can.  

When I was first working on her religion (back in the early development).   I pitched that in some ways her inner emotional core was that of a wartime triage doctor. 
-- Four men come into a field hospital with gunshots wounds. The first one of them took a shot to the head.  Illaoi might be able to save him-- but in the time it takes to do that the other three will bleed to death.  Now she can save those three lives-- if she decides that the first man is going to die.  Day in and day out, Illaoi makes that call without hesitation.  This is the burden of the test she brings...   She doesn't know if people will live through it... but she knows the test has to be done. 

Now from the outside she might even appear to be lawful evil.  -- but I think she's lawful good.    --One of the problems with the old alignment system is it doesn't handle the conflict between internal vs external motivations well.  

still fun to chat about though.

"So with my rose colored glasses- I give her a pass 'cause-- She is completely about the larger good. She knows death isn't the end-- and there are things far worse than death. "

Based on this definition, Karthus is "Lawful Good". What matters more; how the characters perceive _themselves_ and their actions, or what they actually _do_? I agree that Illaoi intends good for those she "helps", but that's little comfort to the people whose souls she rips out and tentacle-slaps. How is this different from Karthus, who we would all agree is "evil"? I mean, you can create a character who believes he's doing good by ripping hearts out of innocents to serve his Heart-Ripper god, but does that make him "good"?

> [{quoted}](name=Merxamers,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=eBOnqZ1v,comment-id=0020000100000001,timestamp=2016-05-16T13:02:20.130+0000)

> I mean, you can create a character who believes he's doing good by ripping hearts out of innocents **to serve his Heart-Ripper god**, but does that make him "good"?


That's not what WAAARGHbobo said about Illaoi, though. He explicitly said that Illaoi was trying to "help people". She's testing people to help them improve if they pass, or to better the universe at large if they fail. Not to please her god. 

Now, I'm no D&D expert, so I don't know if that is good or neutral or lawful or whatever, but that's certainly not evil. And also, she doesn't test random innocents, as far as I can tell. She tests people for a reason, so you can't even say she's evil "by default" because she does not hesitate to harm innocents.

There is a thing like personal opinion of good and good being caring for another.

For example Karthus is more like  a dude who imprisons people in a tower because he legimately thinks he is doing well. He does not care for the people not wanting to be stolen away because he thinks he is right, and does not care to listen them at all in case they have to disagree.

Illaoi's case is more like a mom giving a medicine with a bad taste, even if with more ethical problems involved.

Another example of Evil is the Scarlet Crusade from world of warcraft.

I agree that there is a difference between personal opinion of Good and an objective (if arbitrary) definition of Good, but that's yet another issue.

Illaoi is really acting according to an objective definition, she's not doing just what she thinks is right in her own tortured mind. What raises ethical problems, as you said, is more that she's completely disregarding the short term in favor of the long term, and she's not ready to compromise.

So back to my original point, Illaoi is not doing "good by her God", she's doing "good by the people". She's not doing bad things to please her god, she's doing small bad things for a great good output later.

I think you can say that's where the "lawful" part comes in though.  She feels like the rules of her religion are helpful and adheres to them, but she really seems to lack the kindness, gentleness and selflessness that one generally associates with "goodness".

BUT.  I can definitely see your argument that that's just her personality, not her alignment.  She's lawful good, but she has an abrasive, tough-love personality.  This is where it's easier to assign a plane of afterlife existence than an alignment because they have in-betweens like the plane for lawful neutral/Lawful Good.


All in all though, I really DO see the argument for her being Lawful Good... It's just, generally, for the lawful good alignment, we generally think of" good "as being the primary descriptor and" lawful "being a secondary function and this would not be the case for Illaoi
"-One of the problems with the old alignment system is it doesn't handle the conflict between internal vs external motivations well." That is very true.

The Good alignment in D&D is not above killing people. A Lawful Good paladin would likely execute a murderer for his crimes, after a trial of course. Since she disrupted the order of Bilgewater by I'd want to say she's chaotic, but she doesn't quite fit the arbitrary violence that is chaotic evil. I'd say she either fits chaotic neutral or neutral evil at the moment. If she had deposed Gangplank to help others, not just for her revenge then she could fit Chaotic Good as well.

Nagakabouros and Illaoi's religion stress for people to chase their desires, as that is the way the universe moves towards its destiny. Chaotic favors individuality over the group so this would appear to lend itself towards a Chaotic alignment. Since Illaoi and her god do not seem to advocate for the greater good or wanton violence, I would called her Chaotic neutral.

> {{champion:15}} started as chaotic evil I think. She was blade for hire-- with no qualms about killing innocent people for money.   She's in motion though.

Chaotic Evil is more along the lines of "hahaha, I killed you!!" Chaotic evil is more impulsive and rash doing what it wants in the moment, not caring about what others do and rarely keeps any sort of promise. A mercenary who (mostly) keeps her word, but has no qualms about what her contracts entail would be Lawful Evil or Evil.

> {{champion:238}}  I would say he seems to be chaotic evil... but Ninjas always lie.

Considering Zed is leading an order of shadow ninjas, I'm inclined to consider him Lawful Evil. Chaotic evil wouldn't really be able to maintain any sort of group in the long term.

I'd say Tahm is Lawful Evil. His entire shtick is that he's a crossroads demon, meaning he's all about making a deal and upholding that deal. It's the fault of the people making the bargain with him that he gets to feed on their despair because he can't do it unless they "let him in".

To be Chaotic, you need to be willing to side with anyone or use any means to achieve your goals. Jinx for instance would be just as likely to go skipping through the park with you as she is to blow your head off, it would depend on her mood. Tahm very clearly has his own rules that he follows to a t.

Well he might not go against the rules of his deal,but he does these deals because he wants his "partner" to suffer.

So yeah,he does the deal purely to throw someone into despair,seemingly because he finds it amusing,thats what would make him chaotic(and given his quote about letting him in,I think it is likely that Tahm has to follow the rules out of need,not because he respects them)

You have to remember that all alignments consist of two parts. Chaotic vs. Lawful and Good vs. Evil. Intent to do harm only affects the Good or Evil side of the scale, Chaotic and Lawful are for how a character goes about those desires and intentions.

In D&D and a lot of other similar RPGs there are both Devils and Demons.

Devils are Lawful Evil and use rules and contracts to screw people while also sticking to their word (which is why they pick their words VERY carefully). One example would be classic "Crossroads Devil" situations where people trade their souls for blues fame/musical talent or whatever, which fits Tahm perfectly.

Demons are Chaotic Evil and just love to murder, burn, and rape everything just because they can. A demon gets loose and he'll just go to the nearest town to start setting the world on fire just to watch it burn. Demon's don't make deals, they just kill you, rape you, and eat you, possibly in that order.

Yeah, when we were making him, Tahm was intentionally viewed as a Lawful Evil devil.  BUT I think the classic alignment system has always had problems with inhumane beasts.  As a spirit (or devil if you prefer) Tahm might not exist without people justifying evil and self-destructing.  So the old, Animal= True Neutral argument could be made for him too-- 'cause he needs a specific type of evil to happen like we need food and water.

I'd say the animal=true neutral only applies until sapience is obtained. Tahm is an evil character as he has understanding of what he does. Animal (and plant I guess) neutrality is mostly applicable to Ahri and Zyra out of all League characters.

What do you think about Graves and TF?

Grave's is True Neutral with a bit of Chaotic Neutral.   He has a very strong code he lives by-- but no respect for laws or governments.  

TF is also probably Chaotic neutral with a side of True Neutral.  He has a code he _mostly_ lives by-- but no respect for laws or government.  He's more chaotic than Graves.  

They will avoid hurting innocent people-- but they wouldn't blink before killing someone they thought was "in the game".  (i.e. Gangplank's henchmen etc...)

>A Lawfull good person wants to do good but is likely to find themself struggling or failing to do good because of traditions and adherence to the law.

I kind of disagree.  That sounds more like a lawful neutral who is conflicted.  A lawful Good person would probably say just laws are created for good and unjust laws aren't really laws at all.

To put this into perspective, a funny thing I've noticed is that a paladin's code requires that he is always good but not that he is always be lawful.  Yes he is LG, but he's always going to take the side of good (the higher laws) over the laws of man if you force him to take a side.  He'd rather the two be one in the same and will work towards that end in the big picture but he's got a little leeway on the law side of things when he needs it.

That's because in D&D style alignment lawful doesn't actually mean follow the laws.  Unless it does. Because the writing is inconsistent.  Another version of lawful is following a personal code, which Paladins must do at all times meaning they are by their nature a lawful individual.

Now, this brings the question, why can't a barbarian (which must be chaotic) follow their own personal code?  And the answer to that is: the alignment system doesn't make sense when you really analyze it.

I don't think Gangplank is Lawful Evil. He is a strange area to where it's something like Chaotic and Lawful at the same time and his motives aren't evil, just selfish. Lawful + Chaotic at the same time = neutral.  By this logic, GP is Neutral Evil.  He'll use the law, order, tradition or just the idea of a code of honor and unity if it suits him, but he doesn't really care about any of it and he's just in it for himself.  If someone seems to be kinda back and forth in regards to opposing alignments, it usually means they're neutral and just doing what they feel is the best idea in each circumstance.  MOST people are neutral under the alingment system, actually.  They base their actions more on circumstance, personal attachments and the situation they're in than an overall sense of morality, compassion or honor.

Alignment is very easy to contest too.  I for instance... would put GP as VERY firmly in Evil.  Neutral Evil, probably.  He's a brutal, violent killer that tortures people frequently.  The reason he does this is almost ENTIRELY selfish... so he can "rule" Bilgewater as the pirate king.  He's essentially just a thug and a bully who stays at the top of the pile via the fear other people have of him.  His single "good" act in taking care of a boy who helped him could simply be a pragmatic response.  By rewarding people who help him, he encourages more people to help him.  Even if it is a genuine kind act because he feels for the kid... he's still evil.  Evil characters can have loved ones... they can have moments of compassion or even act nobly from time to time.  They can be charming, friendly or likeable.  But at the end of the day, Gangplank wants what Gangplank wants, and that involves a LOT of theft, murder and brutality.  He'd probably do the same to the kid if he had a reason to... even if he felt bad about it.  

But it's always open to interpretation.  You could see him as CN, while I say NE.  Unless YOU yourself wrote the character and thus are the one deciding how he thinks and acts... alignment is always open to interpretation.  I prefer to use it loosely, going mostly off of a character's actions and how they feel about those actions.  Theft, murder and brutal torture?  Not a speck of remorse or concern that he's causing suffering?  I put him a VERY solid Evil for that... but that's just my opinion.  

Likewise, I could argue that Ekko isn't actually good at all.  Sure, he'd go to bat and lay his life on the line for his friends, his fellow street kids and the like... but if that compassion doesn't extent past people he personally knows and likes it's much more gray.  Now for the record, I don't think this... I would also put Ekko at Chaotic Good.  I'm just saying that the argument could be made that he's only so dogged in what he does because the people involved have a personal connection to him.   Even in this case he's still a pretty light and heroic neutral... but if he'd die for a friend, but ignore the plight of someone outside the "gang" he's protective of... he might fall into neutral.  At least, that's how I'd see it.  I think Riot intends him as CG though, and that he'd stick up for people being bullied, oppressed or mistreated no matter who they are.  I just like that the alignment system is so open and flexible.  It pretty much HAS to be.
